instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
No water damage, no history of any strange things. 


<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 5. 2V
PPBUS - 0.2V 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>  - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> -0 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0 V


LDO on both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> are ok. 


WHen i heat up <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> are it starts sometimes (not always). ALready tried to change <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and stil not booting

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> -0 V"
Fix this first.
Do you get voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>   is generated by <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?


Any idea what it can cause board starting when heat up <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> area ( just sometimes)



Autoreply. It is <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> what make board start when heat up. Will reball it now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> sends out enable for <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
So post few basic voltages for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>MPM_PBUS</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Reballed but something very strange happening. Heating <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> for couple second to 100 degrees make board starts. When it is completly cold it doesnt start. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is dead or about to die? 


I am out now will post voltages tomorrow, but what i think about that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
There maybe other chip which reacts to heat.
Heat reaction appeared after reballed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?
Didn't try that before?

Post mentioned voltages when the board doesn't want to start...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: it was <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Reballed again and working fine. Thank you
